context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Firefighters Battle Massive Brush Fire In College Park
context_meta.summary: BALTIMORE (WJZ) — Fire officials say a brush fire is burning through several acres in College Park. The fire broke out Friday afternoon off of Metzerott Road near the University of Maryland. Chopper 13 is over the scene. Prince George's County Fire spokesperson Mark Brady said in a tweet that the fire was spreading and is near homes in the College Park Woods community and near Cherokee Lane Elementary School. The fire is also burning near a Pepco substation and several powerlines. This is a developing story.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Small brush fire near Greek Theatre prompts evacuation at Griffith Observatory

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Colorado's summer wildfire season could be the worst since 2012 and 2013, state officials say
context_meta.summary: Conditions are setting up what could be the worst summer wildfire season in Colorado since 2012 and 2013, officials said Friday, when devastating blazes ravaged areas across the state. “It appears that this will probably be the worst one, forecast-wise, in quite some time,” said Mike Morgan, director of the Colorado Division of Fire Prevention and Control. “Abnormally dry weather and a dry winter has left our mountains nearly barren.” While state fire officials hedged that it's too early to have a hard-and-fast prediction for what fire conditions will be this summer, things aren't looking up. Snowpack levels, especially in the southeast and southwest parts of the state, are much lower than normal.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Greenland's Biggest Fire Is a 'Warning' for Its Future
context_meta.summary: VIENNA — Last summer, puffs of white appeared in satellite images of western Greenland. These were not patches of snow and ice, but rather plumes of smoke from the island's biggest wildfire on record, burning through miles of thawed peatland. Black carbon particles from smoke plumes can darken Greenland's vast ice sheet, contributing to more heat absorption and more melting. Scientists who studied the wildfire said that nearly a third of the soot landed on Greenland's ice sheet. They warned that much bigger blazes could move through the icy island in the future, and the emissions from these fires could contribute to further melting of the already thinning ice sheet. "I think it's a warning sign

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Hunter burned, homes evacuated in Oklahoma wildfires
context_meta.summary: OKLAHOMA CITY –  An Oklahoma turkey hunter was found alive but badly burned Friday after spending the night trapped by one of two wildfires raging in northwestern Oklahoma that forced about 1,400 people from their homes. The fire that trapped the hunter began Thursday afternoon near Leedey, about 110 miles (177 kilometers) northwest of Oklahoma City and has burned about 82,000 acres (331 sq. kilometers), Oklahoma Forestry Services spokeswoman Michelle Finch-Walker said. Three hunters were trapped, but two were rescued. The man who was burned was hospitalized in serious condition, Finch-Walker said. Dewey County Sheriff Clay Sander said his deputies went door-to-door in the small towns of Seiling,

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Grass fire burns close to Penticton homes
context_meta.summary: The Penticton Fire Department responded to a grass fire in the West Bench area that broke out around 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday. The bush fire ignited behind a home on Spartan Avenue, before spreading along the gully above the popular KVR trail. Witnesses say the fire was fuelled by strong winds. “It was jumping because the wind really started picking up and then it jumped and all of a sudden you couldn't see anything because the fire was starting to gain more and it just blew up from there,” Roxanne Zeiler, an area resident, said. “It went right into our neighbour's yard across the KVR and up.” RCMP shut down traffic in the area. Fire officials say the blaze is under control and no homes were damaged.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Wyden, Oregon succeed with long overdue wildfire fix: Editorial
context_meta.summary: For five years, Sen. Ron Wyden has pushed Congress to address how U.S. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management leaders often must divert money from other programs, including fire prevention and forest management budgets, to cover the increasingly high cost of fighting massive wildfires. Season after season, fire spending consumed an ever-increasing percentage of the federal agencies' relatively flat budgets. Finally, Congress listened and Oregon is likely to benefit. Eventually. The Wildfire Disaster Funding Act was a part of the $1.3 trillion federal spending package passed by federal lawmakers and signed by the president late last month. The act creates an emergency fund of as much as

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Wildfire awareness week arrives in the shadow of SWFL blazes
context_meta.summary: Sunday, April 8 will kick off the Caloosahatchee Forestry Center's Wildfire Awareness week, but a series of blazes across Southwest Florida have let residents know that the danger is already here. Even though the area saw record rainfall and a major hurricane not that long ago, dry and windy conditions have allowed a number of wildfires to consume tens of thousands of acres in Southwest Florida over the last few weeks. Smoke caused repeated road closures in Collier County last week after lighting caused two major fires and one smaller blaze in the Picayune Strand. The two major fires eventually merged into the Greenway fire which burned over 18,000 acres before the Forestry Service shutdown multiple

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Nicaragua forest fire burns almost 9,000 acres
context_meta.summary: A forest fire in Nicaragua that has been burning out of control for a week has blackened almost 9,000 acres (3,585 hectares) in a southern nature reserve. The Indio Maiz reserve is on Nicaragua's border with Costa Rica, but the Nicaraguan government has refused Costa Rican offers of aid. The two countries have had long-running disputes over other areas of their border. Costa Rica's firefighting force said Monday that it was told by Nicaraguan officials that soldiers are being sent to fight the blaze so no Costa Rican help was needed. Nicaragua says it has 800 soldiers, five planes and 10 boats fighting the fire.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Geoengineering risks losers as well as winners for climate and wildfire risks
context_meta.summary: While the international community is already aiming to limit global warming to below 2C by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, the more ambitious aim of a 1.5C limit is known to be challenging to reach in this way. An additional method to further limit warming might be to release sulphur dioxide high in the atmosphere, to produce a thin veil of droplets that would reflect some sunlight back to space and help keep the Earth cool. However, the new research suggests that this method of geoengineering could also introduce its own new impacts by shifting global rainfall patterns. The research by scientists at the University of Exeter and the Met Office Hadley Centre, carried out as part of the EU-funded

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Brush fire forces evacuation of community east of Flagstaff
context_meta.summary: FLAGSTAFF, AZ (3TV/CBS 5) - A fast-moving brush fire has burned dozens of acres and forced people from a community from their homes east of Flagstaff on Sunday. The Arizona State Forestry said the Copley Fire had burned 86 acres. Officials with the Coconino County Sheriff's Office and Coconino County Emergency Management have evacuated the community of Winona, the agency said. About 75 people were at Summit Fire Station until they were allowed to return home, firefighters said. They were allowed back in their homes around 8:30 p.m. Townsend Winona was closed in both directions. The fire started in a home just before 12:30 p.m. and then turned into a brush fire, said Tiffany Davila with the Arizona

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas facing tornado and wildfire threats
context_meta.summary: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - Emergency officials in Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas are bracing for two types of disasters as spring gets into full swing: The start of what's historically the most active time of year for tornadoes plus wildfire threats brought on by severe drought. April, May and June are the most active months in the U.S. for tornadoes. At the same time, the three states on the southern end of Tornado Alley are experiencing extreme and exceptional drought that could fuel wildfires. Tornado Alley extends from northern Texas and covers much of Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska and South Dakota, plus slivers of New Mexico and Colorado, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Wildland fire near U.S. 50 and I-25 bypass
context_meta.summary: Pueblo emergency responders from multiple agencies battled a wildfire near Fountain Creek just south of Highway 50 near the Interstate 25 bypass Wednesday afternoon. The fire was reported to have burned seven acres and was 100 percent contained as of 9 p.m. Wednesday. No injuries were reported, despite the fact the fire took place in an area known to feature numerous homeless camps. Pueblo Fire Department spokesman Erik Duran said the fire is believed to have originated at an established homeless camp in the area, but its direct cause is currently unknown. The area had coincidentally been visited by emergency responders from multiple agencies earlier in the day during a homeless outreach program.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: California fights wildfires aggressively — but prevention takes a back seat
context_meta.summary: Dave Kinateder has a keen eye for trees. “It's a ticking time bomb,” he said, gazing across the dense, green carpet of trees near Quincy, a small community high in the northern Sierra Nevada. Last year's wildfires, the worst in modern California history, have put a microscope on the forests that cover a third of the state–in particular, on managing these wooded lands in ways that would reduce the frequency and intensity of such blazes. California is grappling with the counterintuitive dilemma of too many trees, packed too closely together, robbed of the space they need to thrive—and with how to clear out more than 100 million dead trees, felled by drought or insects, that provide tinder for the next infernos.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Cause of Darien brush fires along Frontage Road undetermined
context_meta.summary: The cause of four small brush fires Sunday along Frontage Road near Lemont Road in Darien has not been determined. Darien- Woodridge Fire Protection District Deputy Chief Darren Leno said Tuesday an investigation was done and the cause could not be determined. The Darien Police Department asked via Twitter on Sunday for anyone who has information about what may have started the fires to contact the Police Department or the fire protection district. A passer-by reported the fires at about 1:55 p.m. April 1, Leno said. There were four separate brush fires on the north side of North Frontage Road just east of Lemont Road, Leno said. Firefighters extinguished the fires. It appeared just dry vegetation

context_meta.title: Brush Fire Prompts Evacuation in Port St. Lucie

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Pacific Northwest firefighters expect another busy season
context_meta.summary: YAKIMA — Wildland firefighters expect the Pacific Northwest will see another busy fire season this year with land around Yakima especially vulnerable. “If I were to pick one place that might experience above-average fire danger, it's the Yakima Valley and the eastern slopes” of the Cascade Mountains, said Josh Clark, a meteorologist with the state Department of Natural Resources. Less rain in the winter, above-average temperatures and less mountain snow mean fires could start earlier and burn longer than a typical season, Clark said. Clark spoke at a conference of wildland firefighters from Alaska, Washington and Oregon held at the Yakima Convention Center. Washington has seen a dramatic increase

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Florida's wildfire season is here: What you need to know
context_meta.summary: The wildfire danger is currently either moderate or high in every Tampa Bay area county. Tampa Bay residents need to know they are at risk if they live near a wooded or conservation area or even swamp land. It is currently Florida's wildfire season, and it is expected to be bad this year, partly because of all the debris left behind by Hurricane Irma. Forestry officials want everyone to take this seriously so they can better prepare their homes in the event of a wildfire. "This is great. They have rocks, cement, they have a chain link fence. All those things help us help them fight that fire," said Florida Foresty spokesperson Judy Tear. Tear showed 10News some simple things one family did, that

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: I-95 near New Smyrna Beach reopens after brush fire
context_meta.summary: Both directions of I-95 near New Smyrna Beach reopened Thursday morning after a brush fire had them closed since Wednesday, the Florida Highway Patrol said. The interstate was shut down between State Road 44 and Dunlawton until about 9:30 a.m., troopers said. Troopers said drivers still need to use caution, as there is some lingering smoke. Troopers said they will continue to monitor I-95 throughout the day. idantonio@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5700

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Hot air balloon crashes and catches fire but no one injured
context_meta.summary: PHOENIX (AP) — Authorities say a hot air balloon carrying 13 people crashed and caught fire Wednesday morning in the desert outside Phoenix, igniting a small brush fire but causing no injuries.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Brush fire closes portion of Alligator Alley in Florida
context_meta.summary: A portion of Interstate 75 known as Alligator Alley is closed due to heavy smoke from a brush fire. Collier County Sheriff's officials said in a Facebook posting that the interstate is closed from the toll booth in Collier County on Florida's Gulf Coast to the toll booth in Broward County. The interstate is the major east-west highway that crosses the state on its southern end. Officials suggest State Road 80 to U.S. 27 as an alternative route for motorists trying to head east. Firefighters have been battling brush fires in southwest Florida since last week.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Portugal volunteers replant trees burnt in devastating wildfire
context_meta.summary: Volunteers in central Portugal planted 67,500 trees on Sunday in the Leiria pine forest as the country recovers from the most devastating forest fires in its history. Leiria's trees were used to build ships that sailed in the 15th and 16th century discoveries when Portugal was a leading maritime nation. Fires struck Portugal in June and October last year and killed 114 people.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Alberta government commits $34.5M towards agricultural societies
context_meta.summary: The Alberta government has announced additional funding for agricultural societies and rural programs. The government said Alberta's 283 agricultural societies will be receiving $11.5 million annually for the next three years to help plan ahead and create budgets for the facilities, events and education they provide in their communities. “I'm pleased that we can continue to support the vital work that agricultural societies do in our province to encourage growth in the agriculture industry and rural Alberta, and educate the next generation of farmers and ranchers,” Agriculture and Forestry Minister Oneil Carlier said. “Ag societies are our partners in delivering many community-centred initiatives,

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Crews On Attack As Fire Burns Close To Homes
context_meta.summary: LARKSPUR, Colo. (CBS4)– Fire crews rushed to put out a grass fire burning near homes in Douglas County on Friday afternoon. The fire was burning near homes on Spruce Mountain Road near Larkspur. Many of the homes were horse properties. The fire has burned about 170 acres and was about 85 percent contained at 2:30 p.m. Copter4 flew over the fire as it spread near homes. Two homes were evacuated and several others were placed on pre-evacuation status. The evacuation for the homes was lifted but the pre-evacuation remained in effect.
